Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Biodiversity of the Gut Microbiome of Herbivorous Rodents
Award.AbstractNarration:
Some of the most critical interactions facilitating mammalian life occur between mammals and the diverse communities of microbes that reside within their guts. Plant-eating mammals harbor the most diverse microbial communities. Many of these microbes are important in the degradation of fiber; however, gut microbes may also play an essential role in detoxifying the natural toxins common in plants. This project will investigate how host evolutionary history and dietary toxins shape the diversity of the gut microbiome of herbivorous mammals by focusing on a group of rodents that specialize in eating plants that are toxic to other animals. Woodrats have an unusually toxic diet spanning a broader array of plants than most species. This makes them a potential model system for insight into this poorly understood but clearly important role of biodiversity in allowing animals to cope with plant defenses. The objectives of this project are to 1) identify and compare the microbial communities across chambers of the rodent gut to understand their function 2) investigate the influences of evolutionary history and dietary toxins in sculpting microbial diversity and function; 3) determine how diversity interacts with the liver of the host to facilitate detoxification. This project will provide some of the first insights into the microbial diversity of wild herbivores and the role that plant toxins play in shaping diversity.

This work will advance our understanding of microbial diversity and may reveal new microbes useful for human probiotics. The discovery of novel microbes and genes associated with detoxification is anticipated; such biological material is of great interest to agricultural scientists wishing to improve husbandry practices in livestock. A one-week summer workshop will be offered annually to middle school students to teach concepts of microbial diversity through the development of interactive computer simulations and games.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals for this project were:

1) Compare the taxonomic, genetic and functional diversity of microbial communities throughout the woodrat digestive tract and feces using 16S rRNA sequencing and comparative metagenomics.

2) Investigate how dietary toxins, geography and host evolutionary history shape microbial diversity and function.

3)) Engage middle-school students to explore basic concepts in gut microbial biodiversity by developing computer simulations and games that make learning both fun and scientifically sound.

 We evaluated microbial communities in herbivorous woodrats from a diversity perspective by collecting woodrats and inventorying regions of the gut using 16S rRNA and shotgun sequencing. For this purpose, we collected wild woodrats from diverse populations, sampling their wild-type microbiome, and then monitoring how laboratory diets, time spent in captivity, and host phylogeny alter diversity and structure of gut microbial communities. We conducted feeding trials and tested whether detoxification function is transferable via microbial (fecal) transplants from evolutionarily and ecologically experienced species to naive species. We also tested whether dietary toxins act as a selective agent that facilitates the establishment and colonization of non-native microflora. We conducted a number of metagenomic inventories to examine microbial community function across different gut regions and species. We investigated how host gene expression might be related to hosting a dense and active foregut microbial community by comparing gene expression of foregut tissues between woodrats (which house a dense and active foregut microbiota) and lab rats (which do not). We have complemented our research with a classical microbiology approach to isolate and culture bacteria from different parts of the woodrat gut and feces to identify specific bacterial taxa involved in the degradation of ingested plant secondary compounds. Through these projects, we explored how host phylogeny as well as biotic and abiotic environments, shape the biodiversity of mammalian gut symbionts. One of our major findings in this study was that while diet and geography strongly influence the microbiome, evolutionary history plays a stronger role.

 Additionally, we expanded on our previous outreach conducting a summer camp for middle school students to explore the gut microbiome through hands on microbiology, laboratory activities, and video game design. 

 Our research has and will have an important impact on a wide range of other disciplines, including conservation biology, mathematics, agricultural research, and human health. There is currently a focus on the interactions of gut microbes in built environments. Our work on how captivity affects the microbiota has applications to conservation as many animals are brought into captivity for breeding. Lost microbial diversity may influence their ability to survive upon release into nature, but incorporating natural diet elements might reduce captivity effects. Further, using our dynamic diet trials and microbial inventories, we collaborated with math-biology modelers to produce a mathematical model capable of describing and predicting bacterial dynamics in the gut ecosystem. This model will be useful in elucidating the bacterial dynamics of the gut microbiota with an input of a wide variety of dietary constituents. 

This project provided training opportunities for 4 graduate students and 8 postdoctoral fellows. It resulted in 35 peer-reviewed publications with a few more in preparation and review.
